contentrichtext.text: {{distinguish|John Douglass (bishop)|John Douglas (archbishop)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Image:BishopJohnDouglas.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Bishop Douglas.]] '''John Douglas''' (14 July 1721 â€“ 18 May 1807) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] scholar and [[Anglican]] [[bishop]]. Douglas was born at [[Pittenweem]], [[Fife]], the son of a shopkeeper, and was educated at [[Dunbar]], [[East Lothian]], and at [[Balliol College, Oxford]], where he took his [[Master of Arts (Oxbridge)|MA]] degree in 1743. As [[chaplain]] to the [[3rd Regiment of Foot Guards]], he was at the [[Battle of Fontenoy]], 1745. He then returned to Balliol as a [[Snell Exhibitioner]]; became Vicar of [[High Ercall]], [[Shropshire]] in 1750; [[Dean and Canons of Windsor|Canon]] of the Eleventh Stall at [[St George's Chapel, Windsor]] in 1762 (to 1776); a member of the chapter of [[St Paul's Cathedral]] in 1777; [[Bishop of Carlisle]] in 1787 (and also [[Dean of Windsor]] in 1788); and [[Bishop of Salisbury]] in 1791. Other honours were the degree of [[Doctor of Divinity|DD]] (1758), and those of Fellow of the [[Royal Society]] and Fellow of the [[Society of Antiquaries of London|Society of Antiquaries]]. Douglas was not an outstanding churchman. He preferred to stay in [[London]] in winter and at fashionable watering places in summer. Under the patronage of the [[Earl of Bath]] he entered into several literary controversies. He defended [[John Milton]] against [[William Lauder (forger)|William Lauder]]'s charge of [[plagiarism]] (1750), and attacked [[David Hume]]'s [[rationalism]] in his ''[[Letter on the Criterion of Miracles]]'' (1754); he went on to criticise the followers of [[John Hutchinson (writer)|John Hutchinson]] in his ''[[Apology for the Clergy]]'' (1755). He also edited [[James Cook|Captain Cook]]'s ''Journals'', and [[Edward Hyde, 1st Earl of Clarendon|Clarendon]]'s ''Diary'' and ''Letters'' (1763).
